ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed more independence in lab and skills writing about my research

By taking this course, I was able to refine my skills in the following procedures: gel electrophoresis, Western blotting, protein quantification, statistical analysis, figure production, and presentation of my work via a formal research paper. Throughout the semester, I gained a deeper understanding of the molecular biology underlying various neurological processes, and my engagement with weekly lab meetings exposed me to intriguing findings in the primary literature.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great course! I am very appreciative to have research count as credit as a junior

The structure of this course is well-suited for independent learning. The research plan and final paper assignments ensure that students plan and understand their research at a detailed level. Furthermore, the flexible course design allows students to pursue a field of research intrinsically interesting to them, allowing for deeper engagement.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would highly recommend this course to any student looking to gain valuable experience in planning, conducting, and presenting independent research. I found it particularly helpful to receive mentor feedback on the research plan and final paper, and these insights will prove valuable in future research settings.  For students who are already conducting research with a faculty member, it is particularly convenient to enroll in this course as it offers academic credit for work the student is already doing. At the same time, students cannot be paid for their work if they are also earning academic credit; this may be important to consider depending on one's circumstances.
